paragraphs: When Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Cats” arrived on Broadway, in 1982, Playbill took a stab at explaining it: “Cats has no plot, no book, no real story line; it is simply an arrangement of 20 of Eliot’s Old Possum poems for dancers and orchestra.” Tom Hooper’s new film adaptation, opening this week, is less of a fever dream. There’s dialogue, for instance; one trailer opens with a voice-over from Judi Dench, who plays a character named Old Deuteronomy. “Tonight is a magical night where I choose the cat that deserves a new life,” she says. “I judge a cat by its soul.” Seems straightforward. And, instead of having actors play human-sized cats, as is done in the stage version, Hooper opted for cat-sized humanoids.

The source material, “Old Possum’s Book of Practical Cats,” is a collection of poems that T. S. Eliot wrote for his godchildren. “The poems were written in the nonsense tradition,” Carolyn Vega, the curator for the Berg Collection, at the New York Public Library, explained recently. Sara Beth Joren, a publicist for the library, chimed in: “And that’s why when people hate on ‘Cats’—like, ‘Oh, there’s no plot.’ It’s just, like, ‘Yeah, there wasn’t supposed to be.’ And, anyway, there is a plot. There’s a cat trying to go to the Heaviside Layer. That’s a plot.”

The two women were waiting for Francesca Hayward, one of the stars of the “Cats” movie. Hayward, a principal dancer in the Royal Ballet, plays Victoria, a graceful white cat—her first film role. Vega was ready to give Hayward a quick Eliot lesson; she had brought out a first edition of “Old Possum” and some photographs of the poet.

Joren had on cat-shaped stud earrings, a leopard-print scarf, and a vintage “CATS LONDON” T-shirt. “My grandmother’s cat was named Jennyanydots, and the first cat living in our home when I was born was Mistoffelees,” she said, name-checking Eliot’s felines. “We’re ‘Cats’ people.”

“I’m trying to remember if I’ve actually seen the musical,” Vega said. She explained that her aunt used to act out bits from the show. “So do I have a real memory of seeing it?” she asked. “Or do I just remember Aunt Debie?”

Hayward walked in, wearing a big black zip-up sweater, her long brown hair loose. Vega showed her the “Old Possum” first edition, and her eyes widened. “I bought one of these, with the same design on the front, for Tom Hooper, as a present,” she said.
Vega said, “You probably know that the poems were written for very specific children—”
“No, I didn’t,” Hayward said. “This is all very educational for me. Old Possum was Eliot’s nickname, right? By one of his friends?”
“Yes, given to him by Ezra Pound,” Vega said.
“Another literary figure of the time,” Vega said, evidently deciding not to go into Pound’s Fascist sympathies.
Hayward paged through the book, pausing to appreciate certain cats. (Noticeably absent from the book was her own character, Victoria—an Andrew Lloyd Webber creation.)

“There was one Eliot poem that was used for the adaptations that’s not in the book, which is Grizabella,” Vega said, referring to the bedraggled cat, apparently a former sex worker, who sings “Memory.” (She’s played by Jennifer Hudson in the film.) “The poem wasn’t included in any of the published books. It was thought that it was too sad for kids.”

Victoria, Hayward explained, has something in common with Grizabella. As the latter tries to win the approval of the other Jellicle Cats, Victoria, the newest member of the gang, frets. “She’s having all these feelings, like, ‘Do I fit in?’ ” Hayward said.

In Hooper’s version, Victoria sings as well as dances; Webber composed a new song, “Beautiful Ghosts,” for her, and Taylor Swift (who plays Bombalurina in the film) helped write the lyrics—in the style of Eliot. (As Swift put it, “If you can’t get T. S. Eliot, get T.S.!”)

When the first trailer for “Cats” dropped, in July, Hayward was working in Mexico. “I hurried to the hotel lobby and got some Wi-Fi, and then I watched it over and over again,” she said. The trailer opens with her character turning to look at the camera, which she called a “kind of gasp moment.” She continued, “I was also just processing the fact that my ears were in a different place. It’s weird to see yourself without your own ears.”

Viewers of the trailer had a strong negative reaction to Hooper’s “digital fur technology,” which had given the actors tails, whiskers, and furry coats without removing their human fingers, toes, knees, lips, noses, or teeth. The backlash was so extreme that Hooper tweaked the C.G.I. for the final cut. Hayward was unruffled. “The cast has taken it with a great sense of humor,” she said. They communicate with one another on a WhatsApp group, sharing funny reactions to the trailer and other “Cats” memes.
“I think people who criticize the trailer haven’t seen the stage version,” Hayward said. “I think we’re making a lot more sense of it for everyone.” ♦
title: Francesca Hayward, the Pick of the Litter in “Cats”
